body:
@joseAndresGomezTovar I'm an idiot: I totally blanked on your comment that the changes were only with the README. Very sorry about that.

@jeking3 There's no problem with the rust build. I just checked locally (just in case I missed something else).
@jeking3 I'm dismissing your review because the changes are in the README only. The actual build is fine.
How do I retry the appveyor build?
Since it's just a README, let's just merge.
The python error was seen in #1817 as well.
@jeking3 that seemed to have fixed it. One of the Travis jobs failed for seemingly unrelated issues.
Issue reproduced locally (gotta love docker containers)... looking into it.

> The changes look okay but without cross testing how do we know they work?

From my reputation. 😉

More seriously, with CocoaPods, we have a linter, so it can build the lib for all platforms (ios/macos here) and different Swift versions. Which means that that we can validate this pull request compatibility by running:
```
pod lib lint --allow-warnings --swift-version=3
pod lib lint --allow-warnings --swift-version=4.0
pod lib lint --allow-warnings --swift-version=4.2
pod lib lint --allow-warnings --swift-version=5.0
```
I've now added a travis job for that.
But if we only lint we're not checking I/O against other languages, so adding a cross test harness would be a better choice.
Now the erlang feature test for TLS is breaking.  See what happens when a language rots because it's not being built?

So erlang 22 includes erlang ssl 9.3 which disables TLS 1.0 and 1.1 by default, but TLSv1.2 doesn't seem to be working either.  I'll have to back down to erlang 21 for now unless someone with some erlang knowledge can fix the TLS feature test.

I understand, but that's not the scope of this PR: I'm only adding compatibility with current Swift syntax here. Adding cross test support is the purpose of a separate Jira (THRIFT-4547, #1660).

And I guess that it will be easier to add tests now that the code actually builds for all Swift versions.
The docker build container has Swift 4.2 installed, so if you can provide the cross test changes as a separate PR I would appreciate seeing it cross tested.  I'll watch for build completion.
Looks good to me; note until I get CI working again for erlang and rust, I'm trying not to merge too much, so if there's a delay that's why.

The dlang unit test async_test is failing for ssl and hanging causing those builds to fail.  This seems to be related to the newer version of dlang in use.  I had upgraded from 2.083 to 2.086.  I'll try to bisect it.
One last thing to take care of, the Xenial Dockerfile isn't working on install of cabal.
The issue with the Xenial build is (hopefully) a server error on the haskell server side.  As such, I'm going to merge this.
Rebase on master please.  The only known build issue (after what I just merged) in on Xenial, which doesn't affect this since Swift isn't installed on that image.  Thanks.
Please rebase on master to clear up most of the Travis CI issues.
@jeking3 test passed
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed in 7 days if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.

The original design of Thrift allows for different protocol and transport in each direction, which is why you see reader and writer transports and protocols.  In practice I'm not sure it is ever used this way.  The go code was likely modeled after the Java or C++ protocol code which still maintains the inputProtocol, outputProtocol, inputTransport, outputTransport semantics.  It looks like the constructors were simplified when go was added, so I see nothing wrong with this further simplification.  The appveyor issue with concurrency_test seems to be happening enough we should look into it again but it isn't related to these changes - that is a C++ concern.
Thanks for the PR. This is indeed harmless, so I'm gonna go ahead and merge this.
@dcelasun @jeking3 tagging you because you reviewed the [original PR](https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/1810)
This issue has been automatically closed due to inactivity. Thank you for your contributions.
What native thrift primitive type is represented as an unordered map?
@dcelasun @jeking3

> I did not add the protection on NewTHeaderTransport level, because I consider that low-level and don't want to make it impossible to explicitly do the double wrapping.

Hmm, this doesn't sound right to me. Is there a real world use case for double wrapping?

> > I did not add the protection on NewTHeaderTransport level, because I consider that low-level and don't want to make it impossible to explicitly do the double wrapping.
> 
> Hmm, this doesn't sound right to me. Is there a real world use case for double wrapping?

For some testing, probably? My main consideration is that if we prevent double wrapping at `NewTHeaderTransport` level, then there's no way to do it. If you feel that's better I'm happy to do it that way.

Without a real use case I think it's better to avoid letting users shoot themselves in the foot, especially since accidental double wrapping is hard to debug.

So yes, please update the PR.
@dcelasun Done. Commit message also updated.

The concept is sound, appending a `_` on to names that clash with keywords is common practice in D.

I don't see any obvious problem with what's been done in the code here, but I'm not familiar with the codebase so that's not worth much.

Great, thanks for taking a look!

Travis failures seem to be unrelated transient errors. I've restarted the build and will merge once everything's green.
Merged, thanks for the PR!
thanks for helping to get this in

> we have separated keys for read and write header key list, so
that for code that's both a server and a client (example: a server that
calls other upstream thrift servers), they don't automatically forward
all headers to their upstream servers, and need to explicitly set which
headers to forward.

I'd rather we do this the other way around. A common use case for headers is passing a trace ID across services to track a request across multiple hops and it'd be great if this happened without user intervention.

If there are headers one doesn't want to forward, it's easy to remove them manually.

> > we have separated keys for read and write header key list, so
> > that for code that's both a server and a client (example: a server that
> > calls other upstream thrift servers), they don't automatically forward
> > all headers to their upstream servers, and need to explicitly set which
> > headers to forward.
> 
> I'd rather we do this the other way around. A common use case for headers is passing a trace ID across services to track a request across multiple hops and it'd be great if this happened without user intervention.
> 
> If there are headers one doesn't want to forward, it's easy to remove them manually.

I think from a security perspective automatically forward all headers sound like a bad idea. Yes auto forward tracing headers is a common use case, but there might be other headers that's inappropriate to forward.

Other reasons I don't want to auto forward are:

1. From https://golang.org/pkg/context/ you can see that as of go 1.12 there's no way to actually remove a value from a context object (a hack to workaround that is that instead of storing a string value, we store a struct with a string and a deleted flag so that when we need to remove a value we just update it with deleted flag set to true, or just treat empty strings as deleted, or something like that)
2. We actually call the reading helper functions [`GetReadHeaderList`](https://godoc.org/github.com/apache/thrift/lib/go/thrift#GetReadHeaderList)/[`SetReadHeaderList`](https://godoc.org/github.com/apache/thrift/lib/go/thrift#SetReadHeaderList). If we want to do auto forward we would need to rename it into `GetHeaderList`/`SetHeaderList` (because there's only one list now), which is a breaking change (but maybe that's OK since that's not in a release yet)

In the current implementation, it would not be too hard for users to forward all/some headers if they have some middleware setup. They just need to add an extra step like:

```
ctx = thrift.SetWriteHeaderList(ctx, thrift.GetReadHeaderList(ctx))  // forward all
```

or

```
var AutoForwardHeaders = []string{
  "Trace",
  "others",
}

ctx = thrift.SetWriteHeaderList(ctx, AutoForwardHeaders)
```

Alternatively, an idea is that we add a field and a function `TSimpleServer`, to setup the header list that auto forwards, and call `SetWriteHeaderList` where we currently inject the read headers into `ctx` right now. So users only need to setup that once before serving and it will work for all requests.

>Alternatively, an idea is that we add a field and a function TSimpleServer, to setup the header list that auto forwards, and call SetWriteHeaderList where we currently inject the read headers into ctx right now. So users only need to setup that once before serving and it will work for all requests.

I implemented that in the fixup commit. Please take another look.

> there's no way to actually remove a value from a context object

> we would need to rename it into GetHeaderList/SetHeaderList (because there's only one list now), which is a breaking change

Both good points, thanks. I've just added some minor comments, then we are good to merge.
I updated the comments based on your suggestion. Please take another look (I also updated the commit message to include the TSimpleServer change).

The commit only added a getter and fixes the timespan conversion from milliseconds.
There is no code fixing the issue that the class does not allow users from changing the timeout in the class instance since http client is created at class construction.

Setting connection timeout property should allow one to update the internal httpclient field’s timeout value, after class construction.
@all: some java guy around who cares to review this?

Pro-Tip: If you mention the JIRA ticket number in the PR it will be aut-linked to the ticket.
http://thrift.apache.org/docs/HowToContribute

i made some mistake!
Merged.

This is a breaking change. Someone more familiar with the PHP client should take a look, but you should at least update [CHANGES.md](https://github.com/apache/thrift/blob/master/CHANGES.md) to mention it.
@dcelasun Done, I am not entirely sure if this is what I was supposed to do (updating the Changes.md file in my branch for 0.13.0). Please have a look.

I found this error : "Must call super constructor in derived class before accessing 'this' or returning from derived constructor" when I am using thrift es6.
It is bug ? How can I avoid that?

@wadeDra does your service derive from another service? E.g. `service Foo extends Base` if so; this PR would fix that particular issue. I'm still trying to figure out why the travis-ci build failed (can't reproduce locally) so I can get this landed. 

FWIW the approach I took for my local build process, was to write codemods / replacements to fix up the output until I could get this landed.

@dbcfd First, thank you for making this PR, and, sorry for the delay in getting back to you. I'll take a look in the next couple of days, but just wanted to let you know.
As per THRIFT-4940 and since there was no further veto from anyone, I'm closing this unmerged now.
I created a ticket for you. Next time please try to follow [our contrib guide](http://thrift.apache.org/docs/HowToContribute). Thank you!
Sorry @Jens-G, thought this fell under trivial change, compiler warning, since it was a rust compiler warning, but it does change the code generator. Will make an issue next time.

```

By installing you accept licenses for the packages.

Making all in hs

Makefile:585: recipe for target 'all-recursive' failed
```
LGTM. Can you add a test as well so it doesn't regress in the future?

A separate Travis build failed due to Quicklisp:

```
debugger invoked on a QL-HTTP:UNEXPECTED-HTTP-STATUS in thread
#<THREAD "main thread" RUNNING {10005205B3}>:
  Unexpected HTTP status for #<URL "http://beta.quicklisp.org/archive/trivial-utf-8/2011-10-01/trivial-utf-8-20111001-darcs.tgz">: 500

Type HELP for debugger help, or (SB-EXT:EXIT) to exit from SBCL.

restarts (invokable by number or by possibly-abbreviated name):
  0: [CONTINUE] Ignore runtime option --eval #<(SIMPLE-ARRAY CHARACTER (204)) (quicklisp:bundle-systems '(#:puri #:usocket #:closer-mop #:trivial-utf-8 #:ieee-floats #:trivial-gray-streams #:alexandria #:bordeaux-threads #:cl-ppcre #:fiasco #:net.didierverna.clon) :to "external... {100173CF9F}>.
  1: [ABORT   ] Skip rest of --eval and --load options.
  2:            Skip to toplevel READ/EVAL/PRINT loop.
  3: [EXIT    ] Exit SBCL (calling #'EXIT, killing the process).

((LAMBDA (QL-HTTP::CONNECTION) :IN QL-HTTP:HTTP-FETCH) #<SB-SYS:FD-STREAM for "socket 10.20.1.31:35108, peer: 99.84.168.70:80" {1003FA6263}>)
   source: (ERROR 'UNEXPECTED-HTTP-STATUS :URL URL :STATUS-CODE (STATUS HEADER))
0] 

No output has been received in the last 10m0s, this potentially indicates a stalled build or something wrong with the build itself.
Check the details on how to adjust your build configuration on: https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/common-build-problems/#build-times-out-because-no-output-was-received
```
Yeah that looks fine. As you've noticed, we have some flaky Haskell and Lisp tests so if everything else passes I'll go ahead and merge this.

Had a dumb mistake where I had `optional binary var default ""` but it should have been `optional binary binvar = ""`. 

I've pushed a fix.

Tests are failing:

```
/thrift/src/lib/java/build/gen-java/thrift/test/StringAndBinary.java:102: error: cannot find symbol
    this.binval = ByteBuffer.wrap("".getBytes());
                  ^
  symbol:   variable ByteBuffer
  location: class StringAndBinary
```
That should have been fully qualified as `java.nio.ByteBuffer`. (fixed it)
Is this something that may be acceptable for integration?
Looks like we have failures in multiple builds. At least _some_ look spurious, but some are more concerning. Rerunning build to try see what's up. @dbcfd
